natural problem: What is the minimum value of $z$ if $z=x^2+2y^2+6x-4y+22?$
natural solution: First, complete the square as follows: $$z=x^2+2y^2+6x-4y+22=\left(x^2+6x\right)+2\left(y^2-2y\right)+22.$$To complete the square, we need to add $\left(\dfrac{6}{2}\right)^2=9$ after the $6x$ and $\left(\dfrac{2}{2}\right)^2=1$ after the $-2y.$ So we have $$z+9+2(1)=\left(x^2+6x+9\right)+2\left(y^2-2y+1\right)+22.$$This gives $$z=\left(x+3\right)^2+2\left(y-1\right)^2+11.$$Now, since $\left(x+3\right)^2\ge0$ and $\left(y-1\right)^2\ge0,$ the minimum value is when both squared terms are equal to $0.$ So the minimum value is $$z=\left(x+3\right)^2+2\left(y-1\right)^2+11=0+2\cdot0+11=\boxed{11}.$$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "z = x powr 2 + 2 * y powr 2 + 6 * x - 4 * y + 22"
shows  "\<exists> (x :: real) (y :: real). z = 11"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the minimum value of $z$ if $z=x^2+2y^2+6x-4y+22?$ The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 First, complete the square as follows: $$z=x^2+2y^2+6x-4y+22=\left(x^2+6x\right)+2\left(y^2-2y\right)+22.$$To complete the square, we need to add $\left(\dfrac{6}{2}\right)^2=9$ after the $6x$ and $\left(\dfrac{2}{2}\right)^2=1$ after the $-2y.$ So we have $$z+9+2(1)=\left(x^2+6x+9\right)+2\left(y^2-2y+1\right)+22.$$This gives $$z=\left(x+3\right)^2+2\left(y-1\right)^2+11.$$Now, since $\left(x+3\right)^2\ge0$ and $\left(y-1\right)^2\ge0,$ the minimum value is when both squared terms are equal to $0.$ So the minimum value is $$z=\left(x+3\right)^2+2\left(y-1\right)^2+11=0+2\cdot0+11=\boxed{11}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "z = x powr 2 + 2 * y powr 2 + 6 * x - 4 * y + 22"
shows  "\<exists> (x :: real) (y :: real). z = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the values of $x$ and $y$ such that $z = x^2 + 2y^2 + 6x - 4y + 22 = 11$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. z = x powr 2 + 2 * y powr 2 + 6 * x - 4 * y + 22"
shows  "z \<ge> 11"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 First, complete the square as follows: $$z=x^2+2y^2+6x-4y+22=\left(x^2+6x\right)+2\left(y^2-2y\right)+22.$$To complete the square, we need to add $\left(\dfrac{6}{2}\right)^2=9$ after the $6x$ and $\left(\dfrac{2}{2}\right)^2=1$ after the $-2y.$ So we have $$z+9+2(1)=\left(x^2+6x+9\right)+2\left(y^2-2y+1\right)+22.$$This gives $$z=\left(x+3\right)^2+2\left(y-1\right)^2+11.$$Now, since $\left(x+3\right)^2\ge0$ and $\left(y-1\right)^2\ge0,$ the minimum value is when both squared terms are equal to $0.$ So the minimum value is $$z=\left(x+3\right)^2+2\left(y-1\right)^2+11=0+2\cdot0+11=\boxed{11}.$$

theorem
fixes x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. z = x powr 2 + 2 * y powr 2 + 6 * x - 4 * y + 22"
shows  "z \<ge> 11"
 proof-

fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. z = x powr 2 + 2 * y powr 2 + 6 * x - 4 * y + 22"
shows  "(LEAST z. \<exists> x y. z = x powr 2 + 2 * y powr 2 + 6 * x - 4 * y + 22) = 11"

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. z = x powr 2 + 2 * y powr 2 + 6 * x - 4 * y + 22"
shows  "(LEAST z. \<exists> x y. z = x powr 2 + 2 * y powr 2 + 6 * x - 4 * y + 22) = 11"

 *)
